ECRP, Customer reprogramming
21.1 Customer reprogramming
� Con?guration Data
Name Mode Coded Limits Display Limits Resolution Unit
NC_REP_USE_CBOOT_UPDATE - 0... FFH 0... 255 1 -
ACTIVE: CBOOT backup is used
INACTIVE: CBOOT backup isn?t used by project
NC_USE_RPG_METHOD - 0... FFH 0... 255 1 -
De?ne customer reprogramming method used.
0: NC_GEN_CUS_RPG
1: NC_SWDL_CUS_RPG
� General information:
The usage of suitable segmented ?ash memories, with the opportunity to delete and (re-) program parts of
the module separately, enables the development of a strategy called reprogramming of the Flash memory at
the customer.
The car manufacturers use this feature in order to delete the Calibration data and/or ECU-SW and/or the
Customer Boot SW and to program them again. With this method it is possible to avoid the exchange of the
ECU when functional changes occur.
The result is a considerable decrease in expenses of the after-sales service for the customer and the supplier.
The activation of the function and the communication actions are done through a unique communication line
(diagnostic communication line) without applying an external voltage to a speci?c pin of the ECU connector.
The ECU memory is divided into main and functional independent parts: Siemens Boot SW, Customer Boot
SW, ECU-SW and Calibration data and potentially Volcano.
The reprogramming function needs always an existing Boot-SW (Siemens and Customer Boot-SW) because all
the software routines for a reprogramming session are located in the Boot component.
The fundamental restriction is that the Siemens Boot SW is not erasable.
The effects resulting from the user actions during a reprogramming session (e.g. key off/key on, false use of the
tool, manipulation) and external disruptions on the communication line are not predictable. So the ECU has to
ensure that unauthorized actions or failures in the reprogramming session have no impact on the operation
of the Boot-SW / ECU-SW or a manipulated ECU is not running in the ECU-SW mode.
� Reference:
REF1: Customer reprogramming (Appli. Inci.) LIMAS speci?cation.
21.1.1 Requirements
The following principle requirements have to be taken into consideration for the implementation of the cus-
tomer reprogramming function:
? The reprogramming function can be used for the end of line and the ?eld programming.
? For the reprogramming function the customer speci?c diagnostic protocol is used.
? The software is divided into independent parts (Siemens Boot-SW, Customer Boot-SW, ECU-SW, Calibra-
tion data and possibly Volcano).
? The reprogramming function needs always an existing Boot-SW (that means Siemens and Customer
Boot-SW).

ECRP, Customer reprogramming
? For the customer it is not possible to reprogram the Siemens Boot-SW.
? There is implemented a backup algorithm to ensure that during the reprogramming cycle, especially
when reprogramming the Customer Boot-SW, there is always a correct Customer Boot-SW.
? Security concept to protect the ECUs against unauthorized manipulation.
? Security concept to avoid the corrupted ECUs when the reprogramming is not correct.
? Information about the reprogramming status of the ECU easily available for the tool.
21.1.2 Functional memory layout
The software is divided into different parts:
? Siemens Boot-SW cannot be reprogrammed through the customer protocol,
size depends on the used ?ash memory.
? Customer Boot-SW reprogrammable, size depends on the used ?ash memory.
? ECU-SW reprogrammable, size depends on the used ?ash memory.
? Calibration data reprogrammable, size depends on the used ?ash memory.
The SW can be con?gured to support more reprogrammable SW parts with the same security mechanisms
(i.e. Volcano).
The above picture shows a principle of the architecture. On each part, the order or the location of security
keys, checksum and logistics ?eld is an example.

CBOOT SW is in charge to erase, to program and to check software component selected.

ECRP, Customer reprogramming
State ?Start? opens a rerpogramming session and check if reprogramming addresses are allowed.
State ?Continue?permits to reprogram data.
State ?Exit?closes a reprogramming session.
State ?Check?performs checks to write security keys for reprogrammed components.
State ?Reset?interrupts reprogramming session.
21.1.3.1.3 Security mechanisms
The effects resulting from user actions during a reprogramming session or caused by unauthorized manipu-
lation are not predictable. So a protection is necessary to avoid erroneous ?ash contents as a consequence of
such an in?uence.
? Checksum (or signature) test to guarantee the validity of the reprogrammed data transmitted. Check-
sum is tested at the end of a reprogramming session.
? Coherence System ensures that reprogrammed SW-parts ?t together. This is tested at the end of repro-
gramming operation.
? Security keys in ?ash memory to secure the reprogramming session if checksum and coherence are
?tting. They are tested at start-up of the ECU. If one of the Security Keys is not valid, the applicative
software is inhibited and there is no system operation.
21.1.3.1.4 Backup mechanism for Customer BOOT SW reprogramming
To avoid an invalid or corrupted Customer Boot-SW there is implemented a special backup mechanism which
guarantees that there is always a valid Customer Boot-SW present in the ECU.
The reprogramming cycle of the Customer Boot-SW is nearly identical to the reprogramming cycle of the other
reprogrammable SW parts except the fact, that in the case of the Customer Boot-SW, the transferred data is
not written to the memory area corresponding to the Customer Boot-SW but to a backup area. After some
checks (CRC checksum, coherence check) the security key for the new backup Customer Boot-SW is written.
At the next startup of the system the new backup Customer Boot-SW is recognized by the Siemens Boot-SW
and is copied to the correct address of the Customer Boot-SW. Only if the copy action and the CRC check were
successful the backup Customer Boot-SW is deleted.
Due to this copy action there are two restrictions:
? The reprogramming of the Customer Boot-SW must be followed by a reprogramming of the SW parts
which overlap with the memory range of the backup area.
The memory range for the backup area of the Customer Boot-SW can be con?gured. It s recommended to
use the memory area used for the Calibration data to keep the following reprogramming session as short as
possible.

21.1.3.2 Software download reprogramming concept
A secondary Boot Loader (SBL) is loaded in RAM by diagnostic services in CBOOT SW as for SV reprogram-
ming.
The SBL is in charge to erase, program and check (CKS operation only) software components selected.
The software download uses the following sequence:
? Switch to Primary Boot Loader (PBL),
? Download Secondary Boot Loader (SBL) into RAM,
? Execute SBL.
The Software Download is divided in two SW parts:
? PBL: designed to be permanently placed in a protected Flash boot sector (CBOOT), which is activated
either on ECU reset or by the Tester via a communication service. The PBL has only for objective to
download in RAM the SBL.
? SBL: designed to be downloaded in RAM by the PBL where it is executed and thereafter deleted after
each use. The SBL can be described as a super set of the PBL, adding functions for erase and write of
?ash Memory.
21.1.3.2.1 PBL description routines
The PBL shall only be able to write data to RAM due to security and data integrity using generic customer
reprogramming modules. Erase of ?ash memory can only occur if SBL is downloaded into RAM.

21.1.3.2.2 SBL description download routines
SBL services include special routines for FLASH erasure and programming.
In order to avoid overwriting the SBL, a new download to RAM is not possible before an ECUReset and Diag-
nosticSessionControl services execution.
Step  Functions  Tester messages (UDS format)  
1 Erase flash sector 
 Routine Control 
2 Request for downloading data into Flash  RequestDownload 
3 Transfer data from tool to ECU 
repeat this step until end of download  TransferData 
4 End of transfer RequestTransferExit 
5 Exit ECU programming session ECUReset

5918Project: VW SIMOS 18.1 EA888 Document key: 10213413 SPE 000 DE
Baseline: SC8L50Y0 Copyright Continental AG

--- Page 7 ---

## Function

The diagram illustrates the software download and reprogramming concept for an automotive ECU. It shows the process of updating the ECU's software, specifically the boot software, using a secondary boot loader (SBL). The process involves a "reprogramming session" and the subsequent "next startup" of the ECU.

## Inputs

*   **New Customer Boot SW:** The new software image to be loaded onto the ECU.
*   **Siemens Boot SW**: Base boot software originally installed on the ECU.
*   Diagnostic Service Requests/Communication Service: The command to initiate the reprogramming process, likely issued by a testing tool or diagnostic equipment.

## Outputs

*   **Updated ECU Software:** The desired state where the ECU's flash memory is updated with the new customer boot software and ECU software/calibration data.
*   **Erase/Program Commands**: Implicitly, the SBL controls the erasure and programming of flash memory.

## Logic Flow

1.  **Reprogramming Session:**
    *   The "new Customer Boot SW" is received by the ECU.
    *   A Backup Area is used for potentially storing the original ECU SW/CAL data.
    *   A primary boot loader (PBL) resides in a protected flash boot sector (CBOOT). This PBL is activated by either an ECU reset or a communication service request.
    *   The PBL downloads a Secondary Boot Loader (SBL) into RAM.
    *   The SBL is responsible for erasing, programming, and checking the new software components. The new Customer Boot SW is written, presumably along with updated ECU SW/CAL data.

2.  **Next Startup:**
    *   After the reprogramming session, at the next startup, the updated "new Customer Boot SW" is used.
    *   The updated ECU software/calibration data is now active within the ECU's flash memory.
    *   The boot process now utilizes the updated "Customer Boot SW", rather than the old one. The Siemens boot software likely provides the foundation for this process.
